content.value: Introduction to Disk & File System Management
Disk and file system management means checking disk usage, identifying storage devices, and mounting or unmounting drives to access data.
In Linux, storage devices such as hard drives, USB drives, and partitions must be mounted before you can use them. Monitoring disk space helps prevent crashes, data loss, and performance issues.

Mounting attaches a device to a folder path so you can access its contents. Unmounting safely disconnects it before removal.

Different file systems are designed for different purposes. Linux commonly uses ext4, while USB drives often use FAT32 or NTFS.
